Mark Damon merged his company MDP Worldwide into Behaviour Communications, the film branch of a Canadian multimedia conglomerate in 1998. After another restructuring, the company changed its name back to MDP Worldwide in May 2000.

The film did not get any subsidies from France's national film support fund, as it was viewed as a commercially-oriented production.
The film did receive some subsidies from the regional governments whose territories were showcased in the picture.

Casting agents struggled to find suitable extras to portray a bygone peasantry, as most modern inhabitants of rural Southern France lacked the rough facial features desired by production, and looked too urban.
The streets of 17th century Paris were recreated in Sarlat-la-Canéda for the film.
The streets of 17th century Paris recreated in Sarlat-la-Canéda served as a replacement for the now demolished fortifications of The Cité de Carcassonne.
The Royal Palace is the redecorated Capitole in Toulouse for the film's Paris location.
The Convent of the Jacobins in Toulouse served as Richelieu's residence for the film.
Both Luxembourg and Belgium were locations for the film's shooting.
The production used Château de Caumont to stand in for the Musketeers' headquarters at Monsieur de Tréville's in the context.
The production used Vianden Castle as the fictional Duchamps Castle, where the film's climactic action scene takes place in the context.
